Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5.3)
revision.text:
'''Energy policy of Belgium''' describes the [[politics of Belgium]] related to energy. [[Energy in Belgium]] describes [[World energy resources and consumption|energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production. consumption and import in [[Belgium]]. [[Electricity sector in Belgium]] is the main article of electricity in Belgium.
Belgium is a federal state. The energy policy is mainly set by the three regions. [[Belgian federal government]], if in place, have jurisdiction in some areas. The federal government have responsibility of the nuclear policy - and closing the nuclear plants. Belgium is a member of the [[European Union]] compling the [[energy policy of the European Union]].
==Climate policy== {{Main| Climate change in Belgium}} At the federal level, Minister [[Paul Magnette]] is in charge of [[politics of global warming]]. Belgium takes part in the [[European Union Emission Trading Scheme]] and [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]]. Belgium has signed the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. Belgium emissions in 2007 were 10 tonnes of carbon dioxide per capita, when the EU 27 average was 7.9 tonnes per capita.<ref>[http://webbshop.cm.se/System/TemplateView.aspx?p=Energimyndigheten&view=default&cat=/Broschyrer&id=e0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f Table 1: Emissions of carbon dioxide in total, per capita and per GDP in EU and OECD countries, 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016045634/http://webbshop.cm.se/System/TemplateView.aspx?p=Energimyndigheten&view=default&cat=%2FBroschyrer&id=e0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f |date=October 16, 2013 }} Energy in Sweden, Facts and figures, The Swedish Energy Agency 2010 Source: IEA/OECD</ref>
EU renewable energy targets of final energy for Belgium is 13% by 2020.<ref name="RENS2008">[http://www.ren21.net/pdf/RE2007_Slides.pdf Renewable energy in the world 2007] Ren21, Worldwatch 2008 Slides</ref>
==Electricity== {{Main|Electricity sector in Belgium}} Electricity was 13% of primary energy use in 2008.<ref name=IEA2010>[http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2010/key_stats_2010.pdf IEA Key energy statistics 2010] Page: Country specific indicator numbers from page 48</ref> According to the [[International Energy Agency|IEA]] statistics the fuels of electricity consumption in 2009 were: 53,8% nuclear, 40,8% fossil, 7,4% renewable and 2% export of production.<ref name=Sverigez>[http://webbshop.cm.se/System/TemplateView.aspx?p=Energimyndigheten&view=default&cat=/Broschyrer&id=e0a2619a83294099a16519a0b5edd26f, Table 49: Specific electricity production per inhabitant with breakdown by power source (kWh/person)] Energy in Sweden, Facts and figures The Swedish Energy Agency 2010 Source: IEA/OECD</ref>
=== Nuclear power === In October 2009, the final version of [[GEMIX]] report commissioned by Minister [[Paul Magnette]] was published. The report studied the energy sources for the years 2020 and 2030. It recommended not to close the old [[nuclear reactor]]s in 2015 as previously planned.<ref>[http://economie.fgov.be/fr/binaries/rapport_gemix_2009_fr_tcm326-76356.pdf Quel mix énergétique idéal pour la Belgique aux horizons 2020 et 2030 ?] [[GEMIX]] report Belgium, September 30, 2009. [[Luc Dufresne]] was president of the workgroup {{fr icon}}</ref> [[Ecolo]] the French-speaking [[green party]] was against keeping them after 2015.
===Renewable electricity=== Existing share of [[renewable energy]] of electricity in Belgium was 2.8% in 2006 and target 6.0% by 2010.<ref name="RENS2008"/>
Belgium was an exception in the central Europe by not having [[feed-in tariff]] FiT for [[wind energy]] in 2007, like e.g. the [[Electricity sector in the Netherlands|Netherlands]], [[Electricity sector in Denmark|Denmark]], [[Electricity sector in Germany|Germany]], [[Electricity sector in Italy|Italy]], [[Electricity sector in Spain|Spain]], [[Electricity sector in France|France]] and [[Electricity sector in Portugal|Portugal]].<ref name="RENS2008"/> Wind electricity production per inhabitant in 2009 was in Belgium 93 kWh/person compared to [[Wind power in Spain|Spain]] 794, [[Wind power in Germany|Germany]] 461, [[Wind power in the Netherlands|the Netherlands]] 278, [[Wind power in the United Kingdom|Britain]] 138 and [[Wind power in France|France]] 121.<ref name="Sverigez"/>
Belgium had in 2007 [[feed-in tariff|FiT]] for small installations of [[Solar power in the European Union|photovoltaic solar power]].<ref name="RENS2008"/>
==Biofuels== Target for [[biofuels]] was in Belgium was 5.75% by 2010.<ref name="RENS2008"/> The EU [[Biofuels Directive]] (2001) requires 5.75% biofuels of transport fuels excluding aviation by December 31, 2010.
==Regional policy==
=== Flemish Region ===
As of 2009, there was 3.3% of [[electricity]] coming from [[renewable energy]].<ref name="livios.be">[http://www.livios.be/nl/_build/_newz/_hot/9345.asp?content=Recordaantal%20nieuwe%20zonnepanelen Recordaantal nieuwe zonnepanelen] 12/10/2009</ref> The [[Flemish Region]] published various ''Beleidsnota energie''. The 2004-2009 version was published by Minister [[Kris Peeters]]. The 2004-2009 version was published by Minister [[Freya Van den Bossche]],on 27 October 2009.<ref name="www2.vlaanderen.be">[http://www2.vlaanderen.be/economie/energiesparen/beleid/beleidsnota_energie_2009-2014.pdf Energie 2009-2014] 27 oktober 2009 Vlaams minister van Energie page 25</ref> This report was partially based on research conducted by [[VITO]].
The Flemish region stated five goals for the government of 2009-2014:<ref name="www2.vlaanderen.be"/> *increase [[efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] of buildings, processes, machines,processes, products and services *reduce the [[energy intensity]] *increase decentralized production *secure electricity and gas at low prices *ensure that the energy remains available and affordable for the poor.
The government target is 9% of renewable electricity in 2014 and 13% in 2020.<ref name="www2.vlaanderen.be"/>
==See also== {{Portal|Belgium|Energy}} {{Commons category|Energy in Belgium}} * [http://www.ewi-vlaanderen.be/sites/default/files/documents/102295-MVG-A5-LR_0.pdf Energy Technology in Flanders 2010] Flemish government * [http://ec.europa.eu/environment/climat/pdf/nap_belgium_final.pdf Draft of Belgian National Allocation Plan for CO2-emission allowances 2008-2012] Brussels.
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{merge|Galactic winds|discuss=Talk:Galactic superwind#Merger proposal|date=March 2018}} [[File:M82 Galaxy from the Mount Lemmon SkyCenter Schulman Telescope courtesy Adam Block.jpg|thumb|[[Messier 82|M82]], a starburst galaxy often referred to as the "Cigar Galaxy", is thought to exhibit strong superwinds.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lehnert|first=Matthew D.|last2=Heckman|first2=Timothy M.|last3=Weaver|first3=Kimberly A.|date=1999-10-01|title=Very Extended X-Ray and Halpha Emission in M82: Implications for the Superwind Phenomenon|journal=The Astrophysical Journal|volume=523|pages=575–584|doi=10.1086/307762|issn=0004-637X|arxiv=astro-ph/9904227|bibcode=1999ApJ...523..575L}}</ref>]] The '''galactic superwind''' is an unusual outflow of highly energetic radiation and material normally observed in [[Starburst galaxy|starburst galaxies]].<ref name="ESO2010">{{Cite web|url=http://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/level5/March01/Heckman/frames.html|title=Galactic Superwinds - T.M. Heckman et al.|website=ned.ipac.caltech.edu|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eso.org/public/news/eso1036/|title=The Superwind Galaxy NGC 4666|last=information@eso.org|website=www.eso.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref>
Galactic superwinds are theorized to occur when [[ejecta]] from [[supernova]]e or [[Solar wind|stellar winds]] interact with enough force that the ejecta's [[kinetic energy]] is converted to [[thermal energy]]. The resulting effect is a massive gust of rapidly expanding super-heated gases that can span the length of a galaxy.<ref name="ESO2010" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heckman|first=Timothy|date=2000-07-15|title=The role of starbursts in the formation of galaxies and active galactic nuclei|url=http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/358/1772/2077|journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London A: Mathematical, Physical and Engineering Sciences|language=en|volume=358|issue=1772|pages=2077–2091|doi=10.1098/rsta.2000.0631|issn=1364-503X|arxiv=astro-ph/9912029}}</ref>
== Galactic superwind formation == Superwinds are theorized to form in compact [[Starburst galaxy|starburst galaxies]] in which star growth is much higher than in other types of galaxies. This accelerated star growth results in more prevalent solar winds being present in starburst galaxies. Superwinds form when ejecta released either by supernovae or solar winds collide with such force that the [[Shock wave|shock]] from the impact converts the kinetic energy of the ejecta into thermal energy. The violent conversion from kinetic to thermal energy prevents a significant amount of energy from being [[Radiation|radiated]] away. This in turn creates an incredibly hot bubble of gas that is under much greater pressure than it surroundings are. Eventually the gas bubble will expand to encompass other particles of ejected gases, further increasing the force and size of its expansion. This "snowplow" effect results in a gust of [[stellar wind]] and gas that can span the width of a galaxy.<ref name="ESO2010" /> A paper produced by the [[California Institute of Technology]] theorized that superwinds can potentially be traveling at a velocity of several thousand kilometers per second by the time they enter the [[intergalactic medium]].<ref name="ESO2010"/>
== References == <references />
[[Category:Stellar evolution]] [[Category:Solar phenomena]] [[Category:Stellar phenomena]]
